Authors:
Claire M Manglicmot, Alejandro Oceguera-Figueroa, Sebastian
Kvist
Title:
Bacterial endosymbionts of Placobdella (Annelida: Hirudinea:
Glossiphoniidae): phylogeny, genetic distance, vertical transmission and
co-speciation
Keywords:
Placobdella; Reichenowia; Rhizobiaceae; intracellular
symbiosis; bacteriomes; phylogeny; co-phylogeny; species diversity
Abstract:
Blood-feeding leeches of the genus Placobdella have
acquired intracellular alphaproteobacterial endosymbionts of the genus
Reichenowia that potentially aid in the production of B vitamins,
thereby ameliorating the lack of these essential nutrients in the diet
of the hosts. Although preliminary evidence suggests that this is an
obligate relationship for both associates, little is still known about
the bacterial diversity, their genetic makeup and the mode of
transmission of bacteria between leeches. Here, we aimed to (i) place
the bacterial symbionts in a phylogenetic context, increasing the
taxonomic sampling more than three-fold, (ii) compare the patterns of
cladogenesis between the bacteria and their hosts to search for evidence
of co- speciation, and (iii) explore the mode of bacterial transmission
between leech parent and offspring. DNA sequencing of the bacterial 16S
rDNA and 23S rDNA loci confirms their presence in ten previously
untested Placobdella species. Bacteriomes for four species were further
subjected to transmission electron microscopy in order to localize the
bacteria. Our results suggest that, whereas Reichenowia forms a
monophyletic group within the alphaproteobacterial family Rhizobiaceae,
no evidence for co-speciation between hosts and bacteria can be traced.
Attempts at DNA amplification using bacterial specific primers for
ovarial tissues were negative for a range of species, but two 16S rDNA
sequences retrieved from the testisacs of P. rugosa showed very high
similarity with Reichenowia. Although we cannot rule out that this may
be a contamination, or a different, potentially free-living species of
bacteria, our results may indicate that Reichenowia are transferred from
leech parent to offspring via the testisacs.
